data.title: McCabe v. Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railway Co.
data.meta_description: McCabe v. Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railway Company, 235 U.S. 151 (1914), was a United States Supreme Court case in which the Court ruled that an Oklahoma law was unconstitutional insofar as it did not provide dining cars and other luxury accommodations for African-American passengers, however the Court also ruled that the litigants were not entitled to equitable relief because they lacked standing to assert constitutional claims on behalf of others.
